title: 113_s2477
content: The Act titled "Egyptian Military Coup Act of 2014" imposes restrictions on foreign assistance in response to the Egyptian military coup d'etat. The Act titled "Egyptian Military Coup Act of 2014" highlights the removal of President Mohamed Morsi by the Egyptian military in 2013, the subsequent violence against protestors, and the restrictions on foreign assistance imposed in response. On January 17, 2014, President Obama signed the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2014, conditioning aid to Egypt on democratic reforms. In April 2014, he approved the transfer of helicopters and financial aid to Egypt's military government. Subsequently, a court in Egypt sentenced 683 citizens to death for protests, and Former Army Chief al-Sisi led a coup against the government. On May 6, 2014, a court in Egypt banned members of the National Democratic Party from participating in any elections. The United States is legally prohibited from providing foreign assistance to any country whose elected head of government is deposed by a military coup. The United States has suspended aid to countries that have experienced military coups, including Ivory Coast, Central African Republic, Thailand, Mali, Fiji, and Honduras. Restrictions on assistance to the Government of Egypt are in place, in accordance with the Department of State, Foreign Operations, and Related Programs Act. The United States has suspended aid to countries that have experienced military coups, including Ivory Coast, Central African Republic, Thailand, Mali, Fiji, and Honduras. Restrictions on assistance to the Government of Egypt include suspending deliveries of defense articles and services until democratic national elections have taken place followed by a peaceful transfer of power. Processing of future arms sales to Egyptian MOD and MOI entities is also halted until the President certifies to Congress. The United States has suspended aid to countries that have experienced military coups, including Ivory Coast, Central African Republic, Thailand, Mali, Fiji, and Honduras. Aid to Egypt is restricted, including halting deliveries of defense articles and services until democratic national elections occur, followed by a peaceful transfer of power. Costs for delays will be covered by the Government of Egypt.
